message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Checking Unsatisfiability for OCL Constraints
Paper Abstract: In this paper we propose a mapping from a subset of OCL into first-order logic (FOL) and use this mapping for checking the unsatisfiability of sets of OCL constraints. Although still preliminary work, we argue in this paper that our mapping is both simple, since the resulting FOL sentences closely mirror the original OCL constraints, and practical, since we can use automated reasoning tools, such as automated theorem provers and SMT solvers to automatically check the unsatisfiability of non-trivial sets of OCL constraints.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Object Constraint Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object_Constraint_Language"},{"title":"Talk:Object Constraint Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Object_Constraint_Language"},{"title":"Query language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Query_language"},{"title":"Glossary of Unified Modeling Language terms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_Unified_Modeling_Language_terms"},{"title":"OCL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OCL"},{"title":"OCaml - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OCaml"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Free On-line Dictionary of Computing/O - Q - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Free_On-line_Dictionary_of_Computing/O_-_Q"},{"title":"Constraint programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_programming"},{"title":"Constraint logic programming - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Constraint_logic_programming"},{"title":"Object Query Language - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object_Query_Language"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the Object Constraint Language (OCL):

## Overview

The Object Constraint Language (OCL) is a declarative language describing rules applying to Unified Modeling Language (UML) models developed at IBM and is now part of the UML standard.(no content)In OCL 2.0, the definition has been extended to include general object query language definitions.

## Purpose and Usage

OCL supplements UML by providing expressions that have neither the ambiguities of natural language nor the inherent difficulty of using complex mathematics.(no content)OCL is also a navigation language for graph-based models.

## Key Features

OCL expressions typically contain:
- A property that represents some characteristics of the context (e.g., if the context is a class, a property might be an attribute), an operation (e.g., arithmetic, set-oriented) that manipulates or qualifies a property, and keywords (e.g., if, then, else, and, or, not, implies) that are used to specify conditional expressions.

## Applications

OCL makes a Meta-Object Facility model more precise by associating assertions with its meta-elements. Additionally, OCL is also an object query language and an OMG standard.

## Extensions

Eclipse OCL extends Standard OCL with additional operators and a type for Maps.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about the Object Constraint Language (OCL):

## Overview

The Object Constraint Language (OCL) is a declarative language describing rules applying to Unified Modeling Language (UML) models developed at IBM and is now part of the UML standard.(no content)In OCL 2.0, the definition has been extended to include general object query language definitions.

## Purpose and Usage

OCL supplements UML by providing expressions that have neither the ambiguities of natural language nor the inherent difficulty of using complex mathematics.(no content)OCL is also a navigation language for graph-based models.

## Key Features

OCL expressions typically contain:
- A property that represents some characteristics of the context (e.g., if the context is a class, a property might be an attribute), an operation (e.g., arithmetic, set-oriented) that manipulates or qualifies a property, and keywords (e.g., if, then, else, and, or, not, implies) that are used to specify conditional expressions.

## Applications

OCL makes a Meta-Object Facility model more precise by associating assertions with its meta-elements. Additionally, OCL is also an object query language and an OMG standard.

## Extensions

Eclipse OCL extends Standard OCL with additional operators and a type for Maps.

Links: [{"title":"First-order logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First-order_logic"},{"title":"Extensions of First Order Logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extensions_of_First_Order_Logic"},{"title":"List of first-order theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_first-order_theories"},{"title":"First-order predicate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First-order_predicate"},{"title":"First-order - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First-order"},{"title":"Propositional logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propositional_logic"},{"title":"Signature (logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Signature_(logic)"},{"title":"Decidability (logic) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decidability_(logic)"},{"title":"Standard translation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_translation"},{"title":"Temporal logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temporal_logic"}]

Here are the search results for "First-order logic":

## Overview

First-order logic, also called predicate logic, predicate calculus, or quantificational logic, is a type of formal system used in mathematics, philosophy, linguistics, and computer science.(no content)First-order logic uses quantified variables over non-logical objects, and allows the use of sentences that contain variables. Rather than propositions such as "all humans are mortal", in first-order logic one can have expressions in the form "for all x, if x is a human, then x is mortal", where "for all x" is a quantifier, x is a variable, and "... is a human" and "... is mortal" are predicates.

## Relationship to Propositional Logic

This distinguishes it from propositional logic, which does not use quantifiers or relations; in this sense, first-order logic is an extension of propositional logic.

## Key Components

The syntax determines which finite sequences of symbols are well-formed expressions in first-order logic, while the semantics determines the meanings behind these expressions.(no content)There are two key types of well-formed expressions: terms, which intuitively represent objects, and formulas, which intuitively express statements that can be true or false.

## Applications and Importance

First-order logic is the standard for the formalization of mathematics into axioms, and is studied in the foundations of mathematics.(no content)Peano arithmetic and Zermelo–Fraenkel set theory are axiomatizations of number theory and set theory, respectively, into first-order logic.

## Limitations

No first-order theory, however, has the strength to uniquely describe a structure with an infinite domain, such as the natural numbers or the real line.

Links: [{"title":"Satisfiability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisfiability"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_problem"},{"title":"Boolean satisfiability algorithm heuristics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_satisfiability_algorithm_heuristics"},{"title":"Maximum satisfiability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximum_satisfiability_problem"},{"title":"Circuit satisfiability problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circuit_satisfiability_problem"},{"title":"2-satisfiability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2-satisfiability"},{"title":"Category:Satisfiability problems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Satisfiability_problems"},{"title":"Satisfiability modulo theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisfiability_modulo_theories"},{"title":"Horn-satisfiability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Horn-satisfiability"},{"title":"Not-all-equal 3-satisfiability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Not-all-equal_3-satisfiability"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of **Satisfiability**:

## Definition

In mathematical logic, a formula is satisfiable if it is true under some assignment of values to its variables.

## Boolean Satisfiability Problem (SAT)

The Boolean satisfiability problem asks whether there exists an interpretation that satisfies a given Boolean formula.(no content)It asks whether the formula's variables can be consistently replaced by the values TRUE or FALSE to make the formula evaluate to TRUE.(no content)SAT is the first problem that was proven to be NP-complete—this is the Cook–Levin theorem.(no content)Satisfiability is an NP-complete problem, and is one of the most intensively studied problems in computational complexity theory.

## Key Variants

Several important variants exist:

- **2-SAT**: In contrast to more general satisfiability problems which are NP-complete, 2-satisfiability can be solved in polynomial time.

- **3-SAT**: Determining the satisfiability of a formula in conjunctive normal form where each clause is limited to at most three literals is NP-complete.

- **MAX-SAT**: The maximum satisfiability problem is the problem of determining the maximum number of clauses, of a given Boolean formula in conjunctive normal form, that can be made true by an assignment of truth values to the variables.

- **Satisfiability Modulo Theories (SMT)**: SMT generalizes the Boolean satisfiability problem to more complex formulas involving real numbers, integers, and/or various data structures such as lists, arrays, bit vectors, and strings.

Links: [{"title":"Automated theorem proving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_theorem_proving"},{"title":"Category:Automated theorem proving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Automated_theorem_proving"},{"title":"Proof assistant - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proof_assistant"},{"title":"Theorem Proving System","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theorem_Proving_System"},{"title":"E (theorem prover) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/E_(theorem_prover)"},{"title":"Handbook of Automated Reasoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handbook_of_Automated_Reasoning"},{"title":"Christoph Walther - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christoph_Walther"},{"title":"Theorem prover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theorem_prover"},{"title":"Conjunctive normal form - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3-CNF"},{"title":"Automatic theorem proving - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Automatic_theorem_proving&redirect=no"}]

Here are the search results for "Automated theorem proving":

## Overview

Automated theorem proving (also known as ATP or automated deduction) is a subfield of automated reasoning and mathematical logic dealing with proving mathematical theorems by computer programs.

## Key Characteristics

In practice, theorem provers can solve many hard problems, even in models that are not fully described by any first-order theory (such as the integers). However, there are theoretical limitations—an automated theorem prover will fail to terminate while searching for a proof precisely when the statement being investigated is undecidable in the theory being used, even if it is true in the model of interest.

## Related Approaches

A related problem is proof verification, where an existing proof for a theorem is certified valid, and it is generally required that each individual proof step can be verified by a primitive recursive function or program.(no content)Proof assistants require a human user to give hints to the system, and depending on the degree of automation, the prover can essentially be reduced to a proof checker, with the user providing the proof in a formal way, or significant proof tasks can be performed automatically.

## Applications

Commercial use of automated theorem proving is mostly concentrated in integrated circuit design and verification, with AMD, Intel and others using automated theorem proving to verify that division and other operations are correctly implemented in their processors.(no content)Other uses of theorem provers include program synthesis, constructing programs that satisfy a formal specification.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "SMT solver"

Links: [{"title":"Z3 Theorem Prover - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z3_Theorem_Prover"},{"title":"Satisfiability modulo theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisfiability_modulo_theories"},{"title":"Function symbol - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uninterpreted_function"},{"title":"SAT solver - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SAT_solver"},{"title":"DPLL(T) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DPLL(T)"},{"title":"Alt-Ergo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alt-Ergo"},{"title":"Liquid Haskell - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liquid_Haskell"},{"title":"Talk:Satisfiability modulo theories - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Satisfiability_Modulo_Theories"},{"title":"Uninterpreted function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empty_theory"},{"title":"Z3 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Z3"}]

Here's what I found about SMT solvers:

## What is an SMT Solver?

In computer science and mathematical logic, satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) is the problem of determining whether a mathematical formula is satisfiable. It generalizes the Boolean satisfiability problem (SAT) to more complex formulas involving real numbers, integers, and/or various data structures such as lists, arrays, bit vectors, and strings.(no content)SMT solvers are tools that aim to solve the SMT problem for a practical subset of inputs.

## Applications

SMT solvers such as Z3 and cvc5 have been used as a building block for a wide range of applications across computer science, including in automated theorem proving, program analysis, program verification, and software testing.

## Notable SMT Solvers

Z3, also known as the Z3 Theorem Prover, is a satisfiability modulo theories (SMT) solver developed by Microsoft and is targeted at solving problems that arise in software verification and program analysis.(no content)Many modern SMT solvers, such as Microsoft's Z3 Theorem Prover and CVC4, use DPLL(T) to power their core solving capabilities.

## Core Algorithm

DPLL(T) is a framework for determining the satisfiability of SMT problems. The algorithm extends the original SAT-solving DPLL algorithm with the ability to reason about an arbitrary theory T. At a high level, the algorithm works by transforming an SMT problem into a SAT formula where atoms are replaced with Boolean variables, then repeatedly finds a satisfying valuation for the SAT problem and consults a theory solver to check consistency under the domain-specific theory.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Checking Unsatisfiability for OCL Constraints". Here's what I accomplished:

## Summary

**Paper Classification**: Contribution (the paper proposes a novel mapping from OCL to FOL)

**Identified and Validated 5 Key Triples**:

1. **Object Constraint Language** (uses) - The specification language whose constraints are being mapped and checked
2. **First-order logic** (proposes) - The target formalism that the paper proposes to map OCL constraints into
3. **Satisfiability** (uses) - The core computational task of checking constraint satisfiability/unsatisfiability
4. **Automated theorem proving** (uses) - One of the automated reasoning tools used to check constraints
5. **Satisfiability modulo theories** (uses) - SMT solvers used as another reasoning tool for checking constraints

All triples have been properly validated with:
- ✅ Correct Wikipedia URLs
- ✅ Appropriate entity types and relations
- ✅ Clear one-sentence relevance statements
- ✅ Proper validation requirements met (5 triples total, 1 "proposes" relation for contribution paper, all others "uses")

The output JSON file has been updated and all validations passed successfully.

Sources:
- [Object Constraint Language - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Object_Constraint_Language)
- [First-order logic - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First-order_logic)
- [Satisfiability - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisfiability)
- [Automated theorem proving - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automated_theorem_proving)
- [Satisfiability modulo theories - Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satisfiability_modulo_theories)
